awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Energy-Harvested Security for the Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet of Things integrates the virtual world of computers into real-world applications, leading to better efficiency, economy and an improved quality of life. This requires a huge amount of tiny computers, and this project addresses the challenge of powering those computers in a sustainable manner. Tiny computers can run off harvested energy sources such as solar, vibration and/or temperature gradient. The project objective is to show how such energy-constrained devices can support secure and full Internet connectivity. This can be achieved by reworking the computations leading up to a secure Internet connection and spreading them out over time. The proposed solution aims to use every harvested Joule of energy towards useful computations.

The project builds on insights from three domains, including cryptographic engineering, energy-harvesting technologies, and formal verification. The harvester-friendly version of a cryptographic algorithm is created by partitioning it in pre-computed steps that generate coupons. Coupons are created when there is a surplus energy, and they can be used to speed up online computations at a later phase. The project optimizes cryptography from the standard Internet stack and integrates it with energy-harvester technology. Verification techniques ensure the functional equivalence of pre-computed versions of Internet protocols to their mainstream counterparts. The project contributes to the research agenda in crucial areas such as lightweight cryptography, formal methods, and realization of energy-harvesting systems. The project will disseminate publications, open-source hardware, and software, and it will establish a programming competition to raise the awareness of energy-constraints in the Internet of Things.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigates the feasibility of running cryptographic protocols from intermittent power sources including energy-harvesting. There is a rich and extensive collection of security protocols to provide information and operational assurance properties of computing platforms. However, existing secure protocols have been designed for continuously powered computers. The proposed approach is to transform secure protocols and cryptographic algorithms such that they can run in small steps. Every step can generate one or more coupons, which represent partially computed or pre-computed results. If the power becomes unavailable, the coupons are preserved in non-volatile memory. When the power returns, the coupons are copied from non-volatile memory to continue the operation.

Intermittent computing has been studied by other researchers, but none of them considered checkpoint security as the major consideration. The proposed research demonstrates that an attacker model can exploit these checkpoints, and the research has developed a computing protocol to protect them. It also shows that the secure computing architectures are critical, especially to support intermittent computing, and such a secure computing architecture is developed through the research.

A secure computing architecture may have impact beyond the embedded computing world, for example, in cloud computing or desktop computing when faced with intermittency of operation. The researchers of this project expanded their research into a new application domain, biomedical security, as a potential driver for Secure Intermittent Computing Protocol (SICP). Biomedical sensors can be wearable, ingestible, injectable, or implantable, and thus form a natural driving application for intermittent operation. The researchers of this project studied the security requirements of biomedical devices and proposed a layered design for the security services on such nodes. They also developed an energy harvesting circuit aimed to power wearable biomedical sensors.

The researchers demonstrated the importance of optimizing the security operations in energy harvesting applications. They showed the need for selecting checkpoint security based on the contents of the checkpoint and how to achieve them. They also demonstrated various design factors that affect the performance of energy harvesting circuits such as the checkpoint size and non-volatile memory type. They demonstrated through experiments the feasibility of using machine learning techniques to synthesize “relational invariants” automatically. They also demonstrated that the feasibility of using a Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) solver to model the cache timing side channel under out-of-order execution accurately and efficiently. In summary, the proposed research has good impact on the feasibility of running cryptographic protocols from intermittent power sources including energy harvesting.
